I think I might have been, until now, misunderstanding a subtlety of 
Domain Scope.  Specifically, in this contrast:

Case 1:
Seed: "www.domain.com"
IN scope: "otherhost.domain.com"

Case 2:
Seed: "department.domain.com"
NOT IN scope: "otherhost.domain.com"

It has been natural (but wrong) for us to think of DomainScope as 
treating the domain immediately above the top level as special, and thus 
assuming it would handle Case 2, even though the documentation is clear 
that it merely strips any leading 'wwwN' prefix, and thus doesn't.  So, 
to get this behavior, is it more correct to change DomainScope, or to 
make a new, different scope?

I suppose you can't really implement this change to the DomainScope 
rules without defining exhaustively "top level domains" for the rules' 
purposes exhaustively (".com", ".is", but also ".co.uk", ".edu.au"), 
since I think the rule inherently wants to be expressed in reference to 
the domain immediately past top level.  (I think I remember Gordon 
making this point sometime in the past.)

Any thoughts?
